As we continue through the month of May, it is crucial to acknowledge its significance as national mental health awareness monthly. This month serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of nurturing our mental well being and fostering understanding and support for those facing mental health challenges. In the midst of our reflections, I'd like to extend my deepest gratitude to Doctor Carl Vincent for his unwavering dedication and support in providing assistance to our brave firefighters and police officers during their times of need. Doctor Vincent's commitment to mental health care for our first responders has been nothing short but of commendable. His tireless efforts have not only offered solace and guidance to those in distress, but have also underscored the vital role mental health plays in the lives of those who serve our community. In honoring national mental Health Awareness Month, let us not only raise awareness, but also extend our support and empathy to all those who may be struggling silently together. Through compassion and understanding, we can create a world where mental health is prioritized, stigma is eradicated, and support is readily available to all who need it. Thank you, Doctor Vincent, for your invaluable contribution and to everyone joining in this collective effort to promote mental well being and create a brighter, more compassionate future for all. With that, I'd like to give Doctor Vincent a little gratitude of ours from the fire department. Thank you so much. Thank you very much. We move to our proclamations. We have a series of them today. chunks.text: Good evening everybody. I call the committee of the whole to order on March 26, 2024 at 06:00 p.m. there is no remote electronic attendance tonight. So we move to our first board appointments, mayors appointment of Kate Jennings to the Moline Commission of Commission on Youth for a full three years term to expire on March 27, 2027. And mayors appointment of Jaiga Thorson to the Public Art Commission to fill the unexpired term of Daniel Oden to expire September 30, 2024. Any question? Next is public comment? Sivg? Has anyone signed up to give public comment? Mister Alison, thank you for coming. And you have three minutes to make your comment. It is our protocol that council does not respond at this time, but if appropriate, we can arrange follow up communication outside this meeting. You have three minutes, sir. Good evening, council. I am Virginia Garfield School senior residents and it is a historical building. As the city of Moline knows, it let a corporation come in and buy up the properties at the old Moline High School and Garfield Grade School. And that company has neglected those buildings. They're historical. And while they neglect the buildings, they neglect the tenants also. Because if you don't care about taking care of a building, what would you care about taking care of a senior? All you want is your money. We went two years with no janitor service. Our floors weren't clean for two years until just recently. This month of March was been the second anniversary. No janitor service due to there was no money in the budget. So the regional manager said to me personally, and we pay some pretty good rent prices in that building. It fluctuates in the different areas. You have square footage of your apartment, some apartments running up to $875, and that's in the old section in 1901, built. And they had some problems with their heating here recently during this storm because of poor building. They didn't put caps on the roof of the heaters that they put in the apartments in the old section of the school, and they got plugged up from the storm. And those people went with algee for almost two weeks, and then the elevator went out, three weeks, no elevator service until they got apart. They never offered the company, Gormans, never offered to do anything for anybody. These seniors on third and second floor couldn't get down the steps because of their disabilities, couldn't go to the grocery store, couldn't go to the laundry room in the building. Gormus didn't care. But the other building over here that the Moline let me build and house tenants there by the molding pool. The morning Star, they call that. Their elevator went up, but they had enough staff to help the tenants. They helped the tenants get the groceries up and down from outside. Upstairs. They had plenty of help. A different corporation. Whoever vetted this, Gorman's company did not do a very good job of vetting them because they own properties all across the United States. And if they would have vetted here, mulling would have vetted that company because they were going to allow them to purchase historical buildings. All right. But they weren't properly vetted because of the neglect that they do to the buildings. They neglected Moline High School and then sold it once they made their money. And what they wanted to do, they never took care of maintenance. It was in bad shape. Enterprise. Have you all went to enterprise lately? Brand new building, got buckets going down the hall, catching water from the ceilings. Thank you very much. Your three minutes is over. Thank you for your presentation. I just want to give you an idea how a corporation is treating the buildings and the people. We have other buildings in Moline that are older, that have housed people longer, have been built since, but those buildings aren't falling apart. Different corporations. Thank you. The next speaker is Claudia. I cannot read the last name. No, they have three. You have three minutes. It's Claudia. Oh, okay, good, Claudia, when we speak Spanish, with permission, may I act as her interpreter? Yes. Thank you, Claudia. You have three minutes. Okay. Joveno Gikomo representante la comon Latina. Jose Venezuelana, paraphandirse, tantalo comunida Latina, Laconomia itambien. Claudia comes here representing the latino community. She's from Venezuela. She is one of the vendors from Mercado on fifth, and she wanted to share with you her experiences selling in Mercado and what it means to community and how it impacts the economy here in our, our great city. Maliko Latina, itambien, the sepue sa roya el turismo. Claudia views Mercado V and her ability to sell. There is a win win between the latino community and the city of Moline, given that it's an opportunity for her to not only contribute additional sales taxes into the city, but also to help with tourism. She views this as an opportunity. She referenced a movie with Jennifer Lopez where it highlighted, I think, our quad city ai

Neglecting building maintenance despite high rent prices.
Mercado on Fifth provides a platform for the Latino community to sell their products, contributing to the local economy and tourism.

And every time I try to get in touch with the. With the authorities, up here is nobody there. I mean, people just not even coming out to even try to find. Let us know what's going on. I called in December because I didn't have no heat for three days. Didn't nobody even come out. I called the building inspectors. I called channel eight. Still nobody come out. So I'm sitting there freezing with no heat. Then all of a sudden the elevators break. We there for three weeks with no elevators. People can't even get downstairs. They had to stay upstairs for three weeks. The man took his mother downstairs because the elevator was broke. She fell down sheltered and died the next week. Thank you. Your three minutes over. Thank you for your presentation. Becky Graves. Hi. Good evening. Thank you. You have three minutes. Okay. Thank you. My name is Vicki Graves. I know some, but not all of you. I am chair of the Moline Plan commission and I'm here tonight because the council has asked plan commission to make recommendations on accessory dwelling units adus. I'm here to ask the council to not take any final action on Adus until there has been sufficient opportunity for the public to provide its input with five new council members. I just want to make sure that there's awareness that the subject of adus was the most contentious issue to come before plan commission in the past decade. There's. You'll be able to see the history of the discussion from the council minutes, but what I want to make sure everyone's clear about is that in 2022, the plan commission voted against adoption of Adus after a public hearing in which residents expressed significant moline specific concerns about the impact of Adus in the city. Members of the public also expressed concern about the lack of information provided in advance about the proposed zoning change and the short notice that was given about the public meetings that were held. Again, this is an important topic with citywide implications. Staff has done a terrific job summarizing information for the commission. chunks.text: adoption of Adus after a public hearing in which residents expressed significant moline specific concerns about the impact of Adus in the city. Members of the public also expressed concern about the lack of information provided in advance about the proposed zoning change and the short notice that was given about the public meetings that were held. Again, this is an important topic with citywide implications. Staff has done a terrific job summarizing information for the commission. We have a draft of an ordinance, but there's still work to be done on the draft and we'll be taking up that work tomorrow at the plan commission meeting. There's. We need to make sure that the draft ordinance aligns with the rental inspection program with short term housing consideration, short term rental restrictions, and make sure there's other alignment along with good development standards. The notice for the public hearing on the ordinance was published in today's paper. The downside of the public hearing process is that public hearings are scheduled during the regular plan commission meetings. That's at 04:00 p.m. on Wednesdays. This is a good time for developers and for the business people who usually attend plan commission and participate in plan commission business. But 04:00 on a weekday is not a good time for people who are working or picking up children from school. I strongly urge that the council arrange for informal public discussions similar to the meetings held at Butterworth center and the library in 2022. I also ask that council ask for feedback through the city's Facebook site and the city's neighborhood groups. You're going to be talking about a housing study tonight, and this is a perfect time to engage with the public to get input on the topic of affordable housing solutions. I've been looking at this for over three years. I'd be happy to talk with anyone of the council about what I've learned so far, the history of the conversation so far in plan commission and city council, and I really urge that this be viewed with an open mind and with attention to citizen concerns. Thank you for your time tonight. I appreciate the council's commitment to affordable housing, to to quality of place, and to seeking citizen input. Thank you. Time is over. Thank you for your presentation. Yolanda Cervantes well, hello there. My name is Yolanda Cervantes and I am. You have three minutes, please. Hello. I am born and raised in Malin and Malin means a lot. Me, I'm second generation here, probably one of the first Hispanics from the Floricenta neighborhood, and I am here representing Mercado on fifth. I request that with the growth that we have and the economic part of it that has happened here in our community, that the requests to have our 12th street closure be accepted. We are growing and it means a lot to our community and we hope that you take that in consideration. Thank you for your presentation. Thank you. Maria Osberos good evening, council. Good morning. Three minutes. Thank you. My name is Maria Antevaros and I appreciate the opportunity to speak tonight. I prepared some short notes so that pregnancy brain doesn't interfere. As many of you know, my grandfather, Bob Antevaros had the original vision of Mercado on Fifth, a place for aspiring entrepreneurs in the Flores Sante neighborhood and throughout the greater Quad cities hispanic community to launch their businesses. Since our pilot season in 2016, so many individuals have come forward, some of them here tonight with their small business dreams of sharing their talents with the community, folks that never knew who to turn to before. And as a result, we've helped to start and provide a platform for over 60 new businesses and have changed the trajectory of many lives. After getting a start at Mercado, for example, Carlos Caudillo of Tacos Avapor that parks up at Zeglins on the avenue. He was able to quit his day job and go full time in his food truck, Dona Mary's Las Salsas, which is right across the street. They were able to test out their menu before opening their restaurant. I also wanted to share one of our vendors. One of our vendors daughters is part of a Latina empowerment group at a middle school in East Moline, and it was assigned to write a poem about the pride of where they come from. And one of our board members was reading through these poems at an event and spotted the following lines. I am from Sylvis, Illinois. Tacos chicken mole from the puesto at Mercado, the Venta de Hoyas on Friday nights, which means from the stand at Mercado, the sale of jewelry on Friday nights. The event means so much to our vendors and their families and with space being tight, we knew we were going to have to make some tough decisions this year. Tears were shed in both of the meetings we had with vendors who were waitlisted. This event also means a lot to the patrons. It's a place where people feel connected to their cultural roots, a vibrant place that makes people feel proud of moline and the quad cities, and a place that sparks jealousy from people outside our community. I would like to thank all the city staff and council members that were involved in the 12th street closure decision and support last year. I can't tell you how much the vendors and patrons appreciated the extra space and safety measures. And I can't tell you how happy it would have made my grandfather for the city to step up as a true partner. As we saw last summer, the event has become bigger than us. We need a long term vision and strategy in partnership with the city to leverage the assets that we've built and to grow the event's cultural and economic impact in a safe manner. I am hopeful that this is the year that we can come to the table together to discuss the future of Mercado. Thank you, Francis Williams, thank you for your presentation. Good evening, council, you have three minutes. Thank you. I'm Francis Williams. I'm the new executive director at Mercado on FIF. I'm just

Good evening, council, you have three minutes. Thank you. I'm Francis Williams. I'm the new executive director at Mercado on FIF. I'm just coming upon my 1st 60 days and within those days, I've been spending a lot of time just listening to understand. And what has become very clear to me is that Mercado means a lot to our city of Malin. I grew up here and we didn't have something like Mercado to celebrate my Latina, you know, heritage. So to have a founder like Bob, like Maria, who had a vision for this and to see where it's come, I'm very grateful for the city stepping in, and I do want to acknowledge that publicly. I know that it was a lot of people coming in last year, very last minute, to try and help us manage with the size of the growth of the events that we had. So I do want to thank everybody for that. It was a lot of. Lot of work and a lot of stress. Stress, I'm sure, on everybody. But with that growth, I just want to share a little bit, since you understand from our founder some of the history I wanted to share. I have a lot of ambitious plans for Mercado. I think with our minority business incubator, we have a lot of opportunity to expand in programming and in education, to live out that value of being in a minority business incubator. Mercado has proven itself to be a safe space for entrepreneurs, particularly those from our minority community, to test their business, not only acumen, but their model, and see if it will take so to have that obviously in our community is such an asset. I hope to continue the collaboration with the City of Moline because I know that our original founders were so intent on having this place in Flora Cente specifically, and in the city of Moline. So to continue to grow and to continue to show that cultural recognition we really do, I will just state publicly how important it is to have the safe aspect of growth in both the Fifth Avenue closure as well as the 12th street closure. Those are going to be able to accommodate us, hopefully for a few years before we get into some new areas, maybe of exploration in alignment with where the city is going for the future development, which I'm very excited about and appreciate, too, that you've given the public the opportunity to. To give comment to those development plans. But our mission continues to stay in alignment with the city, and we will continue to move forward with a collaboration. insights.observation: There is a lack of affordable housing in the community, and this is a primary reason for considering accessory dwelling units (ADUs).
ADUs offer more housing type options for residents and can provide housing for the next generation, including sons and daughters of current residents.
ADUs provide the option for senior citizens to age in place or stay in close proximity to family.
ADUs can convert to other uses over time (e.g., from mother-in-law quarters to independent rental units).
ADUs provide rental income to the owner, serving as an investment opportunity.
The city aims to promote more dense development through ADUs, contrary to urban sprawl.
ADUs will be subject to the new rental inspection ordinance and rental licensing ordinance, and they will not be used for short-term rentals like Airbnbs.

ADUs foster inclusivity and diversity within communities by increasing housing options and accommodating a wider range of household sizes and income levels.
ADUs combat exclusionary zoning practices, promoting socioeconomic diversity and fostering a sense of belonging and inclusiveness among residents.

ADUs offer flexibility and adaptability. They provide homeowners with an opportunity to maximize their use of property, whether it's accommodating aging parents, providing housing for adult children, or generating rental income.

ADUs promote sustainability and urban development by utilizing infrastructure and land. They minimize the need for new construction, thereby reducing the environmental impact and preserving green spaces.
ADUs encourage denser, more walkable neighborhoods and promote community cohesion by reducing the reliance on automobiles.

ADUs contribute to the economic resilience for homeowners by offering a source of supplemental income through rental opportunities, helping to alleviate financial burdens and improve economic stability for tenants.
ADUs provide affordable housing options in desirable neighborhoods, allowing residents to live closer to work, schools, and other amenities.
ADUs foster inclusivity and diversity within communities by increasing housing options and accommodating a wider range of household sizes and income levels.
ADUs combat exclusionary zoning practices, promoting socioeconomic diversity and fostering a sense of belonging and inclusiveness among residents.

I'm very concerned about parking and especially when it comes to snow removal and ambulances and the fire department, because I can tell you a few avenues in Moline where you have to start at one end and you have to wait for somebody to come to the other before you can go because it's that bad.

Also, I have a question about the size of a lot. You say 6500 sqft or larger. If half of that lot or a third of that lot is in a ravine, then that still is the lot size. And so that building could then be pushed in even closer in the existing framework. Correct? So that's correct that a ravine would count towards the minimum lot size? Yeah. And that, I think, is a problem that you need to look at.
This property that you have, this Adu, can also be rented out for two to three months. So you could have people coming and going.

chunks.text: ths. So you could have people coming and going. It's not a case of just it has to have a lease. It could be people coming and going. I know that we are in a situation of where we need additional housing, and I don't see any creativity going as far as looking at expanding on the other side of the river. I think that that is something that the city has always talked about and talks about and talks about. And instead of doing it, all they end up doing is trying to drop more units into smaller spaces. And that's part of the reason why I'm opposed to it. Everybody is talking about this as an investment. Yes. Your property. Yes, it's an investment. You can, you can have income to help you pay for your property, but you're also going to increase the value of your property, and that also means your taxes are going to be going up. So that's what I had to say. Thank you very. Thank you. Next, Barbara Sandberg. Barbara Sandberg, and I'm a member of the historic Preservation commission. Thank you for listening to us today. I wish to express my disapproval for the proposed accessory dwelling unit ordinance. I live in a house in the first ward on 26th Avenue that was built in 1928, the second house to be built in what was then a new neighborhood in a former farm property. As the neighborhood developed, all the houses were set back from the street in a similar distance, as were the garages to the rear of the property set back to allow city alleys. This pattern of neighborhood development would continue throughout the city until the 1950s, when houses were built with attached garages, eliminating the need for our alleys. But these homes too were laid out with similar setbacks from the street or the avenue. This pattern was done to achieve equal visibility and access to individual properties and was aesthetically pleasing to the general layout of the neighborhood. The city has a number of ordinances that protect property owners located in r two single family neighborhoods. The addition of fences is regulated as to placement and height, as is a site of placement of yard sheds. The mowing of grass and shoveling of snow is mandated. The disposal of trash and the regulations that restrict the running of businesses from a home or a garage has also been in place for many years and is kept a neighborhood where the families can live and comfortably and knowing that they're property is protected. Thusly, the city has a neighborhood improvement officer that responds to complaints on these and any other issues that might come up because these are single family r two neighborhoods and these are the background of our city, the introduction of the accessory dwellings to these established neighborhoods opens up the potential for a major change to the aesthetics and the livability of these neighborhoods. If this AdU ordinance is passed, my neighbor could decide to construct an additional building within feet of my property, infringing on my site line and privacy of my backyard and to the others that are in the block. The rental of these structures brings in additional people to an already compact location, along with additional cars that need parking spaces either on the property or on the speed or avenue. My question is, why would moline choose to disrupt established neighborhoods with structures that will occupy what was intended to be open space in our backyards? If an ADu is built next to my property or yours, what will that do to the value of my property in reverse? What would I look at if I were looking for a property and it sat next to an already built Adu and the style maybe was the same as the house to try to make it blend in? Would I even look at that property? I don't think so. Another question is why is this Adu ordinance being discussed again when it was soundly voted down less than two years ago? How many phone calls or emails had the mayor, the city administrator or alderman received asking that it be reintroduced? What prompted all this additional attention? How many petitions have been filed seeking support for the ordinance? I personally am not aware of any strong support for this issue. I've not heard a soul. Most of my friends have all said, well, why would we do this? This is not something they're feeling as an addition to their property value. How many of the public meetings have been held this time to get feedback from property owners after explaining how this ordinance will permanently alter the makeup of their neighborhood, their voices need to be heard. The arguments, we are told, is there is a housing shortage disrupting our established neighborhoods, some of them dating back to nearly 100 years. As is mine is not the answer to the problem. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Frank. I'm sorry. Edge. Hi, Eggie. Thank you, Frank. Eggy. But that would mean if they're married, maybe have another automobile to have sitting out front of the, in the neighborhood. It could also mean that if the children lived there long enough, they would have children who have more vehicles taking up more space on the street. So, and then if I look at my house and I have some grandchildren who just purchased their own homes, affordable homes for them, young people just starting out, they bought houses, they're fixing them up, and they'll have some great places to live in before long. But I look at my home, if I were to have grandparents that I wanted to house in, auxiliary home like that, okay, they pass away at some point. I couldn't rent it. Or if I wanted to move, maybe right now, my house would be worth a couple hundred thousand dollars. That's an affordable home that would sell in a matter of days. But if I added in for a luxury home to the lot, take up a lot of the lot now, what would be the sale price of that home? Would it be 350,000? Is that an affordable home? So what's it going to do to actually having affordable homes? I have probably around my area or nearby, I probably have five, six neighbors who have lots that would be big enough to do that. But it would make the neighborhood look not very good, not very appealing anymore if they all did that. So some things to think about. So thank you. Thank you, Dick Potter. Thank you, Dick Potter. A little bit. 1136 25th street. First of all, as a former alderman, I want to thank you for your service. Often relied on recommendations from the planning commission, and I appreciate all your efforts. My concern is, I guess I'm sort of torn on this. I listened to some of the people on four, and they were talking about how things already exist, and we're going to deal with that because they're already here. And my biggest concern is enforcement. I was around when the last comp plan was passed. I was intimately involved in working with the planning commission on all those things. And one of the things that we worked on was when we created the two reals district, was to prevent single family homes from being converted to duplexes or triflexes. And we have considerable problems with rental property. I am beyond enthralled that the city council has passed the rental housing inspection ordinance. And I guess my concern becomes it would, I would, I would feel much more inclined to be supportive of this if I could feel as though the rental housing inspection program was up and running and well, and that we could, we could deal with that issue like I said, I'm not as concerned about parking. I'm not as concerned about some of the other issues that folks are talking about. My concern is some of the effect about enforcement. I know you talked about restrictive covenants. Who is going to follow up on that when the property gets sold? We have a long history of not dealing with rental problems or rental housing problems. Just some things to think about. Got brought back, and since I was on council at the time, and I did vote against it, and the reason that I would have passed, we could have passed it, and we wanted to pass it at that time. I will tell you the reason it got brought back. It was a bad ordinance. It wasn't. We had, we had amended it a few times, and it just needed to come back and get redone. It wasn't a matter of it was soundly defeated or any of that. It was just, it wasn't written really well. And to that end, I just want to thank this body. But very specifically, we have new staff, we have competent staff at this time, who's really put the energy into getting this thing right. We've addressed, we've addressed the enforcement issues. We've addressed a lot of the issues that were problems in the ordinance. So this was more or less just getting it right. And that's the reason that it's come back this time. I'll piggyback off of Commissioner Moyer, not alderman. Yeah. So I was here for the last public hearing in December of 2022, and I was a no vote philosophically like Mister Potter. I think it's a great policy. However, as a newcomer to the city, I had just moved here about six months prior. I too had concerns about the rental industry here on both sides of the river. And so my loudest objection was that if we want to introduce more rental units to our city, we ought to be able to make sure we have quality places to live. You know, we see what happened across the river when, when inspections are ignored and such. And so that was my big concern. I too, thank the staff. I think you guys have done an incredible job over the last year, plus really fixing out some of the wrinkles in there. And so I've got some other comments, but I'll save them. No, you can carry on a couple of thoughts here. There was some idea that we could open up some neighborhoods south of the Rock river. And so I want to touch on that. And there's a really, a really incredible book out there. I encourage everyone to look for it. It's called strong towns. And what it touches on is the way that we've developed our communities largely since World War two has been a combination of things. But a big part of it has been using tax increment financing to build out neighborhoods, build out commercial spaces. And what happens is those deals run for about 30 years. At the end of 30 years as a developer, you have a choice. Do I put money back into an aging area, an aging place, or do I go seek out a new tax friendly deal from a community? And so what happens is you start spreading out that city over and over and over and over again and it stretches out the cost to maintain that city, the infrastructure. I was at a city council meeting last year that they talked about the cost to maintain our roads here is going to be about $7 million this year. That's taxpayer money. We have 275 miles of Centerline Road in the city here. And if we were to increase and continually to expand out and search for those new open spaces, that number is only going to grow higher and higher and higher. And that is not sustainable long term. And so I think there is opportunity south of the Rock river, but we've got to be conscious of what that means for more police, more sewer, more snow plow, more staff to maintain all of that stuff. And so it's not as simple of just opening up and going beyond that. Cities that have been successful in this, they've encouraged it. They haven't just opened it up. There's a community in the state of New York that has allowed for forgivable loans to build adus for their residents. I'm not saying that that's something that we should do here, but rather than just open it up and say, hey, it's there, take it if you want it, maybe lean into it, it encourages people that are outside of our community to come in and perhaps think of, hey, this could be a place where I can build a family. I can bring my family something of that nature. And so for that, I would say I'm in favor of this. Last but not least, we talked about loans. And how do you find a loan for these? Well, October 2023, the Federal Housing Administration approved or updated their policy to allow you to obtain a bank loan to build one of these. So if you're a prospective home buyer and you want to purchase a home and build an ADu, whether that's ground up construction, new unit with an ADU, you can use anywhere from 50% to 75% of that rental income as an approval mechanism for that loan. So again, we talk about affordability. This allows for new people into our community. And so again, for that reason, I'm in favor of this. Thank you. Hi. I just want to make a few comments. So my interest is in all of you and this board that have really gone back and forth on this. Not all in favor, but we've talked it through. So it's not been a light decision by anyone. It's not. It hasn't. My other thing is you mentioned that, you know, you have the lady that left, she has neighbors that have seven people in the home. The only thing I can tell you is now when you do this, you have to register, so you're on the books. I mean, we've really tried. We tried with the inspection aspect of it and the rental inspection aspect of it. We tried to really touch on a lot of these concerns. None of this was done lightheartedly by any means. I thank you for your comments. You have great comments and made really good points. There are eyesores everywhere in this city. My husband and I have pride in our home, pride in our land. We have a neighbor next door that has a dilapidated, several things, trees growing up through their deck in the back. It's horrible. And I have gone over there and begged them to let me clean it up. So it's not just about building an Aud. I wish I had an aud that he built that had to match his house, that looked right, that had to follow the rules, because what I have now is a dilapidated playground equipment that is horrible and trees just growing straight up and down that encroach on my property. So it's never going to be perfect. We do the best that we can, but I just think there's been many, many good reasons, and this board really tried to make sure we had everything covered to the best of our ability so that these were built the way they should be and had to follow the rules, and that's all. So I just want to make one point, just as Mister Matthias said, so what's in front of us is a draft ordinance. Alderperson Timian made reference to the fact that this current draft was based in part on the work of what was done in 2022. I do want to make a couple of clarifying comments just to make sure that there's understanding of what is different from the 2022 ordinance, to the point about there having been a lot of back and forth. So one difference between the draft that was in front of city council in 2022 that was first voted down by plan commission and then ultimately voted down by city council, there was a requirement for a special use permit. I have said before, in fact, I spoke to city council about my concern about the fact that on the 2022 version of this ordinance, there were two public meetings, and certain representations were made to the participants there about what was in the ordinance. So one of the questions that was asked in that meeting was, will neighbors be notified of neighbors plan to build an AdU? And the answer at that time was yes. Neighbors within 250ft would be notified of a neighbor's plan to build an ADU. In this draft of the ordinance, there is no requirement for special use permit. Neighbors will not be notified of the neighbor's intention to build an accessory dwelling unit. Another distinction between the 2022 draft and the current draft, and again, what was described in the public meetings in 2022 is that there would be a requirement of a lease. It started out as a one year lease. It was changed at city council to a six month lease. That is no longer a provision in this draft, that the requirement is only that there be no short term rentals, meaning no rentals under 30 days, but rentals could be successive 30 day rentals. And I think someone made reference to it could be several, you know, several periods of rental, different renters over a period of time, and in the absence of any kind of lease requirement. That is correct that the rental ordinance simply allows or prohibits rentals under 30 days and allows rentals of 30 days or more successively. Another comment that was made related to the rental register. If an ADU is rented by a family member, the current rental ordinance does not require rental registration. If the ADU is rented by a family member, as that is defined in the rental ordinance, and it's by blood, it excludes, for example, cousins. And in a previous draft of the ordinance, there was proposed change, the definition of family that is no longer in here. Under the current definition of family, you can have up to three unrelated people living in any dwelling unit with a. With an ADU, you could have three unrelated people in the principal dwelling, three up to three unrelated people in the ADU, for a total of six unrelated people, the lot. And there was a proposal to change that to five per dwelling unit. That is not in this current. insights.observation: New homes with ADUs can use rental income for loan approval, improving affordability and allowing more people into the community.
There are issues with eyesores and dilapidated properties which affect community aesthetics and neighbor relations.
The current draft ordinance does not notify neighbors of plans to build an accessory dwelling unit (ADU).
The current draft ordinance allows successive 30-day rentals and does not require longer lease terms.
The rental ordinance does not require registration if an ADU is rented by a family member.
Current draft allows up to three unrelated people in the main dwelling and three in the ADU, totaling six unrelated people on the lot.

chunks.text: Good evening, everyone. Call this meeting to order here in council chambers at 06:00 p.m. we do not have electronic attendance tonight, so we will move to roll call. Please. Alderperson? Murphy? Present. Macias? Present. Rezaq? Present. Timian? Present. Finch? Present. McNeil? Present. Castro? Present. Schmidt. Present. All right. Okay, so we'll start with our presentations. Presentation of Life Saving award to Sergeant Tyler McLaughlin and Officer Tyler Lewis Bresnahan, chief golf. Thank you, mayor. The officers come forward. I appreciate you giving me the opportunity to recognize two very fine officers for some heroic deeds. On March 9, 2024, at 06:12 p.m. the Millennium Police Department received a 911 call of a traffic crash. Officers discovered that a 1999 Chevy s ten had gone off the road in the 2700 block of 6th Avenue, flipped over and crashed, but was able to continue driving to the 200 block of 43rd Street. Officer Lewis Brusn and Sergeant McLaughlin arrived and observed a damaged truck parked in the roadway with blood all over the truck and the ground. The driver was laying on the ground just outside the driver's side door and covered in bright red blood. He was barely conscious and unable to communicate. The passenger was kneeling down over the driver, screaming for help. Officer Louis Brosnahan began to administer first aid. Police found the driver's left arm badly injured. The flesh from the driver's arm from the middle of the bicep to just below the elbow was gone, exposing bone and tendons. It was evident that the driver had suffered massive trauma to his arm, including his brachial artery. Sergeant McLaughlin quickly took out his tourniquet and handed it to Officer Louis Bresnahan, who was now kneeling down on the driver's left side. He instructed Officer Louis Bresnahan to put the tourniquet on and assisted in manipulating it around the driver's arm. Officer Lewis Brezzahan finished securing the tourniquet high and tight on the driver's arm, which ultimately stopped the bleeding before Moline fire arrived on scene. Officer Lewis Bresnahan then assisted Moline fire with loading the driver up on the gurney. The driver was still in critical condition and was transported to the hospital. It was later learned that during the crash, the vehicle rolled onto the driver's side. The driver's left arm was out of the window and became pinned between the vehicle and the pavement and his arm. Was drug along the pavement with the vehicle on top of it for approximately 30ft. While at the hospital, the driver had lost so much blood that the veins in his upper extremities collapsed. The phlebotomist had to take medical blood drop from his foot. The hospital staff left the tourniquet that officer Louis Bresnahan had fixed on while the driver went through all the testing. During this, hospital, staff was replenishing the driver's blood and he was now conscious and alert. The driver ultimately had to be airlifted to another hospital. Officer Lewis Brazihan and Sergeant McLaughlin showed tremendous courage and training throughout the incident. Their actions and ability to stay calm and work together through an extremely chaotic and stressful situation are admirable. The driver was already unconscious when the police arrived, indicating he had sustained significant blood loss. A human can perish from arterial blood loss in as little as three to five minutes. Sergeant McLaughlin and Officer Lewis Presidenthan saved the driver's life during this incident. Their quick thinking and application of the tourniquet stopped the driver from bleeding out any more than he already had. Their immediate recognition of the arterial bleed and the need for a tourniquet to stop the bleeding was critical in saving of the driver's life. Sergeant Joe Cleaver nominated Officer Louis Presidenthan and Sergeant McLaughlin to be considered for the Millennium Police Department's Life Saving award. The nomination was reviewed by the awards committee and sent to the office of the police chief. After review of the award recommendation, I find that life saving awards should be bestowed upon Sergeant Louis president and Sergeant McAllen. I'm sorry. Officer Louis Bresnahan and Sergeant McGaughin. Both officers committed an act performed in the line of duty with prompt and alert action which resulted in saving a human life. So today I'm going to award them a certificate as well as a uniform citation bar to honor this occasion. And so they both read the same life saving award. The city of Moline Police Department awards to officer Titus Lewis Presenhan and of course, Sergeant Tyler McLaughlin. The lifesaving award for your bravery and heroic action that led to the saving of a human life as demonstrated on March 9, 2024. Signed this day, April of 2024, by Chie

We have a need for more housing without land options, buying land options, and Adus offers that with minimal visual impact and without adding to an area's sprawl. And Adus provide a more dispersed and incremental way of adding homes to a new neighborhood than other options, such as multi story apartment buildings. And as a result, it's often easier to get community support for Adus than for other housing types. But there's other important reasons for myself and for my husband. I want to stay in my home for as long as possible. And I know that if I have an adu that provides a separate living space for either family members or for somebody to come in. I look at this as multigenerational. I look at this as allowing families to stay in place as long as possible, and adus can be switched. Mister Vitas mayor and council, at long last, take a breath. It's been a long ride. This project had had its start probably even before I got here in 21. Much to her credit, Alex Elias had been studying residential development along the Fourth Avenue corridor to try and bring new residential living downtown. This property, though probably not directly a part of that study that was done, was directly adjoining it and was a parking lot and adjoining parking lot owned by at that time, the Riverstone group. Riverstone Group, to their credit, decided to donate this property to renew Mulwane and Renew Moline's leadership decided, through their board, to acquire this property for the intended purpose of redevelopment. At that time, this piece of property, of course, had stood vacant from the time that Riverstone had vacated the premise and built a new headquarters across the river. Working with Renew Moline, and working with the development partners at Busch Construction who actually were brought to us by renew Moline, we started a long journey with discussion about where could residential development happen along Fifth Avenue in particular, did not start at this location. It actually started further to the west. But that property became unavailable, and we then moved to the possibility that this property could become a residential development in our downtown, bringing additional, as I've always said, additional wallets and purses to the streets of Moline downtown to support our small businesses and to provide much needed housing, workforce level or rate housing downtown. So the project itself, before you tonight, will allow for the conversion of the vacant office to multifamily residential. There will be 32 market rate units that will be brought to the existing JC Penney building. That includes adding a third additional story somewhat recessed from the edge of the current building. Based on our form based code, commercial tenant area is planned to be a daycare run by Western Illinois University, and there is a letter agreement between Bush construction and Western University to that effect. And in the play area which you just previously approved is at 1719 5th Avenue and 3000. That lot would be reserved specifically for the daycare. To meet the legal requirements, the city approved the gap funding of this project of $2.8 million in the 2024 budget, which will be repaid through the new TIF district that this council created, TIF 15, which is the Fifth Avenue TIF. Bush has secured their letter of intent from Western Indian University to occupy, and I am mistaken, 4000 sqft, not 3000. The park space is 3000 and it's anticipated that the new TIF, created in March 2021, will be the basis for the refunding of the $2.8 million loan that the city is putting into this project. And I will note for those listening that this is the first time that the city has partnered to this level historically, at any time that I'm aware of in order to attract a project with the rising interest rates. When we started this discussion, interest rates were at 6%. By the time we got to the point of having a format, interest rates were at 7%. Where they're sitting at right now for construction loans, they are at 8%. So to Bush's credit, they are basically taking that 1% risk to try and get this project up and running it off the ground. So kudos to them for that. With that, we will be providing, over the course of the time, the last money will actually be the last money in be the first money in off the top. So kind of a LiFO approach, and they agreed to that. There's additionally, in addition to that, this would provide for eleven studio units at about 950 a month. One bedroom units. Parking lot they will retain, which will be uses a lay down yard, same rate that we're charging the Leclaire apartment building property. So with that, we're recommending approval of the agreement. insights.observation: ADUs (Accessory Dwelling Units) promote more dense development, contrary to urban sprawl.
ADUs offer the option for senior citizens to age in place or stay in close proximity to family.
ADU cannot be used as a short-term rental and must be rented for at least 30 days.
No requirement for additional parking for the ADU, but converting a garage to an ADU requires replacement of parking spaces for the single-family home.
ADUs must match the single-family home in architectural style, exterior materials, and colors.
Minimum lot size for an ADU is 6500 sqft, with a lot coverage requirement of 35%.
Livable space limitation of 1000 sqft for an ADU.
Detached ADUs are required to meet specific setback requirements.

insights.observation: The housing study is aimed at analyzing housing needs and fair housing impediments. Historical findings suggest there is an excess of single-family homes, potentially excluding people.
There is ongoing data collection to understand the current housing landscape better, which aims to be more inclusive by addressing potential exclusions due to excessive single-family housing.
A restriction that only one living quarter is allowed per ADU is in place, preventing the creation of duplexes in ADUs.
ADUs must comply with specific lot size and coverage requirements; people cannot just pour parking pads off the road, implementing zoning and urban planning standards.
Replacement of required parking spaces for principal structures when converting a garage to ADU is mandatory, enforcing urban planning regulations.
The community has shown more support than opposition for ADUs, with major concerns being addressed by retaining the owner-occupancy requirement.
Owner-occupancy requirements aim to combat the rollover of residential housing to large landlord companies, thus promoting local ownership.
After extensive discussions and considerations, the ADU ordinance process was seen as good governance with careful attention to community concerns.
Discussion on allowing minor home occupations (like music lessons) in ADUs, which are currently allowed in homes, reflects community engagement in addressing modern housing needs.

insights.observation: The new mobile video equipment is solar-powered with a gas backup generator to ensure continuous operation during bad weather.
The mobile video equipment will be shared between the City of Moline and Rock Island County Sheriff’s Office, promoting collaboration and resource sharing.
The new equipment will be used to monitor public safety during events and potentially reduce criminal activities such as burglary at construction sites.
The video equipment integrates with the city’s existing video management system to ensure continuity and compliance with current policies for access and constitutional policing.
There are established priorities and a calendar system for the shared use of the equipment between the City of Moline and the Sheriff's Office to ensure proper coordination.
The equipment retains video data in compliance with the existing video retention policies, ensuring data privacy and security.

chunks.text: Good evening, everyone. This committee of the whole meeting to order here in council chambers at 06:00 p.m. mister Schmidt is joining us just a few minutes late, and Mister McNeil will not be with us this evening. So we do have a forum, but there's no remote electronic attendance, so we'll start with our oaths of office. Chief thank you very much, mayor. These are always really fun times as the police chief, to recognize the hard work of fellow officers in the Millennium Police Department and tell you how proud you should be of the men and women that work at the Millennium Police Department. I know I am, and this is a great opportunity to make a couple of promotions, so I appreciate the time today. First up, I'd like to introduce you to Andrew Ross Raya. He is a seasoned law enforcement professional with a distinguished career spanning 15 years. He's a proud native of Moline, graduated Moline High School and pursued higher education at Western Illinois University right here at our Quad Cities campus where he earned a bachelor's degree in criminal justice. Andrew is a first generation Mexican American with proud immigrant parents who came to Moline for a better life for their family and their children. Andrew certainly has made them proud of their decision to move here to Moline. Andrew is fluent in Spanish and has added vital bilingual skills to our department to help serve our hispanic community in various roles throughout his career in Moline. Deputy Chief Raya is a 2022 graduate of the FBI National Academy class 282, a prestigious law enforcement ten week executive management program held in Quantico, Virginia. Andrew began his career on patrol, making a significant impact in the Flora Siente neighborhood. His exemplary performance led to assignments with the Illinois State Police, Quincy's Metropolitan Enforcement Group, where he served as an undercover narcotics detective, and later with an assignment with the Department of Justice Drug Enforcement Agency. Andrew was promoted as sergeant in 2017 and returned to patrol as a first line supervisor. In 2018, he transitioned to roles as the sergeant overseeing the community policing unit. In 2020, Andrew was promoted to the rank of lieutenant and returned to the patrol division as the division commander. In 2021, he was appointed commander of the role of Criminal Investigation Division, overseeing the juvenile unit, adult unit, gun unit, Street Crimes Unit and Crime Prevention Unit. Beyond his departmental duties, Andrew has played pivotal roles in various specialized units outside of the department, including since 2020, serving as a supervisor for the Rock Anon County Integrity Task Force, contributing efforts aimed at maintaining integrity and professionalism within law enforcement community. Additionally, he served as the crisis containment unit tactical commander from 2016 to 2021, demonstrating his experience as a team leader and tactical commander in high pressure situations. Last month, Andrew went through a rigorous process for evaluation for the position of deputy chief. I was joined by malayan police deputy Chief Steve van Heisen, Rock island police chief Rich Landy, and retired Davenport police Chief Paul Sikorsky, as well as our human resources department director, Leah Miller, in the evaluation of the candidates. We were all impressed with his performance, leading me to select Andrew as the next deputy chief for the Mawlen Police Department. Andrew is certainly proud. His family are here. With a lot of family members here today, including his wife, Alyssa, who is here, his two children, Olivia, six, and Oscar, three. His dad, Arturo, is here, Kelly and Dale, in laws Samantha and Santana, his sisters and Nick, his brother in law. So, mayor, I'd be honored if you would afford to read the oath of office. Renew Moline paid $10,000 for an artist to manage a selection process and partnered with the city for building space and installation, resulting in the mural designed to express the importance of its location.
The city of Moline authorized the execution of an agreement with Quad City Towing, Inc. to provide towing services based on their history of responsible service.

insights.observation: Preliminary financial analysis for the construction of a solar farm which includes cost-benefit ratios, funding availability, and possible financial incentives.
Municipal usage of 13.35 gigawatt hours of energy can potentially be reduced with the construction of the solar farm.
Potential community benefits include lower utility costs for municipal buildings and lower taxes for constituents due to reduced municipal expenditures.
Reduction in overall carbon footprint with the implementation of the solar farm.
Opportunities for additional revenue generation like the lavender production farms in between the solar rows.
Recommendation for the city to engage with Terra Engineering for construction administration and observation services to ensure compliance with contract documents.
Factoring in potential damage to solar panels from natural disasters like tornadoes and the necessity for insurance and contingencies.
City workers would be required to maintain the solar farm, with an unknown budget for this maintenance.
Considering whether the city should be the owner-operator of the solar farm or engage in a public-private partnership.
Models will need to account for diminishing returns in energy production over time due to panel inefficiencies and replacements.
